content: We were proud to join the Tiŋmiaqsiuġvik River boat ramp ribbon cutting. The new ramp, located near Nuiqsut and the Willow project, will be used by local residents for subsistence and recreational activities and is a testament to our collaboration with the community.

The Willow Project is 80 miles east of Point Barrow in Alaska. It's rural. No motels. This means more man camps will be built. Man camps are notorious for sex trafficking & sexual assault on Indigenous women. This isn't just about protecting land but Native women as well. #MMIWG

I’m very disappointed in the President for approving the Willow Project. Youth voter turnout was at its highest in 2020 & young folks supported him because of commitments such as “no more drilling on federal land”. That commitment has been broken. We deserve a livable future.

We’d like to thank our community for sending more than 16,000 emails urging the Department of the Interior to stop the Willow Project. Today’s decision is a blow to the community of Nuiqsut, Arctic wildlife, and the global climate.

The Willow project has been estimated to produce 287 million tons of carbon dioxide — the equivalent of the annual emissions from 76 coal plants — and cause nearly $20 billion in climate change-related damages. The only acceptable Willow project is no Willow project. #StopWillow

This is a big win for climate, Arctic Indigenous communities, & polar bears!

On Wednesday, U.S. District Judge Sharon Gleason rejected the permits for ConocoPhillips’s Willow oil drilling project in Alaska. The project was expected to produce 100,000 barrels of oil daily for 30 years.

HUGE WIN! A federal judge just threw out permits for the Willow Project – ConocoPhillips’ oil & gas development in Alaska that would’ve produced 160,000+ barrels of oil a day!

This is a big win for climate, Arctic Indigenous communities, & polar bears!
